definition: navy (archaic)/person employed to post messages on the Internet (abbr. for 網絡水軍|网络水军[Wang3 luo4 shui3 jun1])
water/river/liquid/beverage/additional charges or income/(of clothes) classifier for number of washes

sentences.english: XuanZu ordered a ban tortoiseshell ship water-forces, encountered opposition from adm. yi sun-sin.
sentences.chinese: 宣祖下令水軍禁止建造龜甲船，遭到了李舜臣的反對。

sentences.english: It sounds like you are one of those "rebel" #$%$' hired internet trolls.
sentences.chinese: 聽起來，你就像是那些“叛軍”僱傭的水軍之一。

sentences.english: Insiders say "water army" are seriously affecting the credibility of the Internet.
sentences.chinese: 內部人員說“水軍”嚴重影響到互聯網的可信度。

sentences.english: My practice: By this time, the net navy as a spy has appeared behind Haidilao.
sentences.chinese: 此時，海底撈的背後浮現了網絡水軍的諜影。

sentences.english: And that means, the battle ahead with the Internet Water Army will be long and hard.
sentences.chinese: 這意味着，與互聯網水軍的戰鬥將是漫長而艱鉅的。

sentences.english: How do you think of online 'water army'?

definition: "sensational headline writers", people who write misleading titles in order to generate clicks from Internet users/clickbait
national security (abbr. for 國家安全|国家安全[guo2 jia1 an1 quan2])/national security act/state security agency
angry youth/positive term used to describe young Chinese with extreme nationalistic tendencies/see also 糞青|粪青[fen4 qing1]
frightening words to scare people (idiom); alarmist talk/reds under the beds
Diaoyu Islands, claimed by China but controlled by Japan as the Senkaku Islands, also called the Pinnacle Islands
to cheat in an online game (abbr. for 開外掛|开外挂[kai1 wai4 gua4])/(coll.) unbelievably good
military banner/flag signal/(fig.) banner (i.e. false pretenses)
(of a sports competition or match) to commence/(of a war or battle) to break out/to perform acrobatic or choreographed fighting (in Chinese opera)/to brawl/to come to blows
